Typhlops bibroni —
Boettger, 1889: 293
;
Werner, 1898: 143
;

, fig. 24, 1937:

subSubSection.paragraph:
1978: 10; Jacobsen & Haacke, 1980: 8 , fig.; Coborn, 1991: 110 , fig.; O’Shea, 2007: 95 .
Onychocephalus bibroni —
Matschie, 1890: 609 .
Typhlops (Onychocepahlus) bibronii —
Müller, 1890: 690 .
Typhlops bribroni
(sic)— Roux, 1907b: 733 .
Rhinotyphlops bibronii
— Broadley & Wallach, 2000: 167 .

Description. Snout rounded in dorsal view, obtusely angular in lateral view. Rostral oval, slightly pointed behind; frontal subtrapezoidal, supraocular transverse, its lateral apex between preocular and ocular, or failing to reach preocular (NMZB-UM 12431), fused with preocular in NMZB 8401; eye beneath or behind the anterior border of the ocular; nasal sulcus arising from the first labial; SIP T-II-O (N2, P/O, O, O); MSR 30–34, reduction A/B 0 to 2, B/C 2 to 6; MD 363–453 (mean 417.6, n = 30); vertebrae 188–223 (mean 207.5, n = 18); MD/V ratio 1.89–2.14 (mean 2.01, n = 18); L/D ratio 31–42 (mean 35.2, n = 11). Uniform dark brown to blackish above and below, or lighter below. Underside of head and cloacal region always unpigmented. Largest specimen ( PEM 12575 —Mvubukazi River tributary, Cape Province , South Africa ) has a total length of 484 mm .
Distribution. South Africa , Lesotho , Swaziland and extreme southeastern Botswana , with isolated relict populations on the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe , 0–2000 m ( Fig. 14 ).
